channel.title: 经济学人
channel.description: 这是一个追踪经济学人news的种子

item.title: 2010 年代，反腐浪潮席卷整个拉丁美洲。在巴西，Lava Jato 是最著名的活动之一。十年过去了，人们对腐败的看法却日益恶化：
item.description:
A wave of anti-corruption activity swept across Latin America in the 2010s. In Brazil, Lava Jato was one of the most famous. Ten years on, perceptions of corruption are worsening: https://t.co/gV1UTjFKmS pic.twitter.com/30HoCP4JiR

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 在 ChatGPT 时代，欧洲的经济水平与磁带时代相同。这种对比既比看起来更糟糕，也比看起来更好：
item.description:
Europe’s economy is at the same level in the age of ChatGPT as it was at the time of cassette tapes. That comparison is both worse and better than it looks: https://t.co/mXQOfAQCk9 pic.twitter.com/ZMu3lbSmwo

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 本周的 "Money Talks "节目将探讨基础设施投资是否终于迎来了它的春天？请收听播客： 🎧
item.description:
This week on “Money Talks”, is investing in infrastructure finally having its moment? Listen to the podcast: https://t.co/cmSFEbrNs8 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 这六本书有助于解释中东一个世纪的暴力事件 👇
item.description:
These six books help explain a century of violence in the Middle East https://t.co/jQiN2tis0C 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 一位 60 岁的独腿卡车司机拥有近半个世纪在美国高速公路上行驶的经验，他是如何卷入美国最致命的人口走私企图之一的呢？
item.description:
How did a 60-year-old, one-legged truck driver with nearly half a century of experience on America’s interstates find himself involved in one of the country’s deadliest people-smuggling attempts?

1843 magazine investigates https://t.co/InqNtL0oaV

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 对工作充满热情是件好事。但你可能正沉浸在某种不完全健康的情绪中👇。
item.description:
It is great to feel passion for your job. But you may be in the grip of something that is not entirely healthy https://t.co/fRpE16Z5PX 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 经济学家说，社会必须在制造枪支和黄油之间做出选择--随着国防开支的需求变得明显，这个问题再次出现。长期以来，欧洲人放弃了这两者，而选择在海滩上消磨时光👇。
item.description:
Economists speak of societies having to pick between making guns or butter—a question that has resurfaced as the need for defence spending has become apparent. Europeans have long forsaken both to spend time at the beach https://t.co/K5f4AD7epz 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: @t_wainwright 告诉 "The Intelligence"，电影院可能正在消亡，但 IMAX 和高端影院正在蓬勃发展
item.description:
Cinemas might be dying, @t_wainwright tells “The Intelligence”, but IMAX and the high-end are thriving https://t.co/2sTNgtKkzk pic.twitter.com/0UA1TYgJNy

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 研究人员利用人工智能筛选了数千小时的监控录像，确定了纽约五区约 5,000 个脚手架搭设点，发现其中 500 个没有许可证👇。
item.description:
Using AI to sift through thousands of hours of dashcam footage, researchers have identified some 5,000 scaffolding sites across all five boroughs of New York, of which 500 were found to have no permit https://t.co/nbffrD5FKz 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 珀西瓦尔-埃弗雷特的《詹姆斯》对马克-吐温的经典故事进行了一番想象。它加入了作家将边缘化人物拖入新（旧）故事中心的悠久传统👇。
item.description:
Percival Everett’s “James” imagines Mark Twain’s classic tale with a twist. It joins a long tradition of writers who have dragged marginalised characters into the centre of new (old) tales https://t.co/aQq7318SPV 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 生命的 U 形弯曲--为何始于 46 👇?
item.description:
The U-bend of life—and why it begins at 46 https://t.co/gjLwjuCAvC 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 学习是人工智能的基础。但它是如何工作的呢？请参阅我们的 "巴贝奇 "特别系列，了解人工智能革命的科学基础。
item.description:
Learning is fundamental to artificial intelligence. But how does it work? Check out our special series on the science that built the AI revolution, on “Babbage” https://t.co/AdEHnUUsjg

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 一位精神分析师解释了为什么对感到 "疲惫不堪 "的人来说，仅仅尝试放松并不总是有效 👇
item.description:
A psychoanalyst explains why for people feeling “burnt out”, simply trying to relax doesn’t always work https://t.co/FhvBUDw03x 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 对许多俄罗斯人来说，为让弗拉基米尔-普京再次当选而采取的胁迫手段会留下不好的后遗症。选举的结果是注定的，但选举之后的结果却不是 👇
item.description:
For many Russians, the coercion employed to get Vladimir Putin reconfirmed will leave a bad aftertaste.

The election’s result was predetermined; what comes after it is not https://t.co/C9EU0brQ94 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 许多右翼政客煽动年轻人的不满情绪，而许多左翼政客几乎不承认他们有真正的问题。双方都没有很好地解决导致 Z 世代分裂的深层弊病 👇。
item.description:
Many politicians on the right are stoking young men’s grievances, while many on the left barely acknowledge that they have real problems. What neither side has done well is to tackle the underlying ills that are dividing Gen Z https://t.co/zdvG29TDsL 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 美国 11 月的总统大选与其说是一场人气竞赛，不如说是一场全民公决，看美国人认为哪位候选人是最不坏的选择。经济学人》正在追踪这场角逐。收藏此页 👇
item.description:
America’s presidential election in November will be less a popularity contest than a referendum on which candidate Americans think is the least bad option. The Economist is tracking the contest. Bookmark this page https://t.co/75G0ZIB8YS 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 在 "智慧 "节目中@VinjeruM 参观金丝雀码头--伦敦的玻璃钢商业区，该区正在转型以适应在家办公的世界
item.description:
On “The Intelligence” @VinjeruM visits Canary Wharf, a glass-and-steel London business district that is transforming itself to fit a work-from-home world https://t.co/Z78xlGCozN pic.twitter.com/8UMEcuJ5Ly

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 新政府不可能使海地摆脱不安全和非法状态 👇
item.description:
A new government is unlikely to free Haiti from insecurity and illegitimacy https://t.co/t9WkOBtfJX 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 沙子无处不在。然而，只有某种沙子可以用来制造智能手机和太阳能电池板所需的超清玻璃。中国正在寻找二氧化硅浓度超过 99.9% 👇 的砂粒。
item.description:
Sand is everywhere. Yet only a certain sort can be used to make the ultra-­clear glass required for smartphones and solar panels. China is hunting for grains with a silica concentration of more than 99.9% https://t.co/TI026OPrCE 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 美国经济强劲，但选民并不看好乔-拜登。在 "制衡 "节目中： 🎧 @S_Rabinovitch 谈经济繁荣背后的原因 🎧 美联储的作用 🎧 @nealemahoney 谈选民为何不开心
item.description:
The American economy is strong, but voters aren’t giving Joe Biden credit. On “Checks and Balance”: https://t.co/1GAcdCSHak

🎧 @S_Rabinovitch on what’s behind the boom
🎧 The role of the Federal Reserve
🎧 @nealemahoney on why voters aren’t happier

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: "这些积极的数字可能掩盖了令人担忧的趋势"。@doug_dowson 告诉 "The Intelligence"，美国毕业生人数的增加实际上并不是一个好兆头。收听播客： 🎧
item.description:
“These positive figures may be obscuring worrying trends.” @doug_dowson tells “The Intelligence” how America’s rising number of graduates is not, in fact, a good sign. Listen to the podcast: https://t.co/04t8QnhZix 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 俄勒冈州的毒品非刑罪化实验已经失败。它很可能成为一个警示故事👇。
item.description:
Oregon has concluded that its experiment with drug decriminalisation has failed. It is likely to become a cautionary tale https://t.co/AeWkehuKMe 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 加沙的部族长期以来一直是权力掮客。现在，非政府组织正在间接雇用该地区最大的家族提供服务，以保护并帮助向这片无法无天的领土上绝望的人们分发援助物资 👇。
item.description:
Gaza’s clans have long been power­-brokers. Now NGOs are indirectly employing the services of the region’s biggest families to protect and help distribute aid to the lawless territory’s desperate people https://t.co/Nr6C6gQmAo 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 私募股权公司坐拥创纪录的 26 亿美元 "干粉"--投资者承诺但尚未投资的资本。这种情况会如何解决？ 👇
item.description:
Private-equity firms are sitting on a record $2.6trn­-worth of “dry powder”—capital committed by investors, but not yet invested. How might the situation resolve itself? https://t.co/qJ0j4I3uAA 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 大瘟疫后的美国经济令人惊叹，尤其是与其他国家相比。通货膨胀率正在下降，股市屡创新高，普通民众也越来越乐观。但好日子还能继续吗？
item.description:
America’s post­-pandemic economy has been a marvel, es­pecially in comparison to other countries. Inflation is falling, the stockmarket is hitting new records and ordinary folk are growing more optimistic. But can the good times roll on? https://t.co/HfrpnCxcPe pic.twitter.com/Sq9gYSnCQC

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 美国大流行病后的经济是一个奇迹，尤其是与其他国家相比。有三个因素支撑着它的实力 👇
item.description:
America’s post­-pandemic economy has been a marvel, es­pecially in comparison to other countries. Three factors underpin its strength https://t.co/DR8btzNhkS 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 印度的美元百万富翁队伍正在逐年扩大。但有两个风险可能会阻碍他们的增长 👇
item.description:
The ranks of India’s dollar millionaires are expanding year by year. But two risks could stall their growth https://t.co/sVOXptWcnN 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: ♦️ 乔-拜登（Joe Biden）的筹款活动让民主党人的金库更加充实。♦️ 唐纳德-特朗普（Donald Trump）警告说，如果他输了，将面临一场 "血洗"。♦️ 政府又一次部分停摆迫在眉睫。关注美国政治的最新动态： 👇
item.description:
♦️ Joe Biden’s fundraising haul adds to Democrats’ coffers.

♦️ Donald Trump warns of a “bloodbath” should he lose.

♦️ Another partial government shutdown looms.

Follow the latest in American politics: https://t.co/SMYRgv6ZrM 👇 pic.twitter.com/4x9qt7O0gm

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 今天的 "情报 "节目：美国在让更多学生及格方面的失败、伦敦商业区的大流行病教训以及高端电影如何蓬勃发展。收听每日播客： 👇
item.description:
Today on “The Intelligence”: America’s failings in passing more students, pandemic lessons from a London business district, and how high-end cinema is thriving. Listen to the daily podcast: https://t.co/B5a26nnfHk 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024

item.title: 几乎没有一天不在为人工智能让另一家公司的市值突破屋顶而兴奋不已。但是，哪些企业才是人工智能热潮中真正的赢家？ 💸
item.description:
Barely a day goes by without excitement about artificial intelligence sending another company’s market value through the roof.

But which businesses are real winners in the AI boom—and which will win in the longer run? https://t.co/1ZSAxSuaDw 💸

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 18, 2024
